content: How can I help you today?

I guess I'm here because my wife pushed me to come. Things just feel overwhelming lately, with my son acting out, the strain on our marriage, and my general inability to focus or feel happy. I’m not really sure how this works, though.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like there's been a lot on your plate lately with your son, your marriage, and how you've been feeling overall. It can be tough to manage when everything feels overwhelming. Since this is new for you, we can take things slow. What has been weighing on you the most right now?

I think it’s my son. His behavior has been so challenging, and I just don’t know how to help him. My wife and I are trying, but it’s caused so much tension between us. We’re both exhausted, and I’m scared it’s going to tear our family apart.

It sounds like you’re really carrying a lot of concern for your son and the impact it’s having on your family. You want to help him and keep your family strong, but it feels like a heavy weight right now. How do you and your wife usually navigate challenges like this together?

We used to communicate better, I think. Lately, though, it feels like we’re just arguing or blaming each other, which doesn’t help anything. We’re so focused on my son’s behavior that we barely even talk about anything else, let alone spend quality time together.

It seems like the stress around your son’s behavior has made it hard for you and your wife to connect the way you used to, and that feels frustrating and maybe even a little isolating. What has helped the two of you reconnect in the past when things have been difficult?

Honestly, I’m not sure. It’s been so long since we’ve really felt connected. I guess we used to make time for each other, even if it was just something small like watching a movie together or going for a walk, but those moments seem impossible now. It feels like everything is just about surviving the day.

It sounds like the weight of everything has made it hard for the two of you to find even a moment for yourselves, and that’s been tough because you used to have those small connections that helped you feel closer. What do you think has made it so hard to make time for each other lately?

I guess it’s because so much of our energy goes into dealing with our son’s behavior. By the time the day is over, we’re both completely drained, and there’s just nothing left to give. It’s hard to even imagine having the energy to prioritize us right now.

It sounds like you’re giving so much of yourself to trying to handle everything with your son that there isn’t much left over for you or your relationship. That must be exhausting. How are you taking care of yourself through all of this?

Honestly, I don’t think I am taking care of myself. I’m just so focused on everything else that I don’t even think about what I need. It’s like there’s no time or space to even figure that out right now.

It seems like your energy is so consumed by everything else that your own needs have been pushed to the side. That can be incredibly draining over time. What do you think might help make even a little space for you to start taking care of yourself?
I really don’t know. Even thinking about making space for myself feels selfish because there’s just so much going on. I don’t know where I’d even start.

It sounds like the idea of focusing on yourself feels difficult because there’s so much happening, and it’s hard to imagine setting that aside—especially when your family needs you. At the same time, it seems like part of you is wondering what it might feel like to carve out even a small space to recharge. What are your thoughts about that?

I guess I know it’s something I need to do, but it feels impossible right now. Like, how can I focus on myself when things feel like they’re falling apart at home? Maybe I just don’t know how to let myself believe it’s okay to pause and focus on me for a bit.

It sounds like you’re torn—you recognize that taking a little time for yourself might help, but there’s this guilt or fear that if you do, things at home might get even worse. It’s a tough spot to be in. What do you think helps you feel it’s okay to take care of yourself when you’re carrying so much?
Honestly, I don’t really feel like it’s okay. I feel like if I’m not constantly trying to fix things, it means I’m failing my son or my family. I just don’t know how to let go of that.

It seems like you’ve been holding onto a lot of responsibility, feeling like you need to be constantly working to fix everything for your family, and letting go of that feels almost like you’re letting them down. That’s such a heavy burden to bear. What do you think might happen if you gave yourself permission, even just for a little while, to focus on what you need?

I’m not sure. I guess part of me worries that if I focus on myself, things will only get worse. But maybe the other part of me hopes it could help me get through the stress and show up better for my family. It’s just hard to trust that it’d be okay to take that step.

You’re really grappling with this idea—it’s hard to let go of the fear that things might get worse, but there’s also that small part of you that sees how taking care of yourself might actually help you be there for your family in the way you want to. What might it look like to take one small step toward that, in a way that feels manageable for you right now?
